questions.text: A 15 days old child is brought to the paediatric emergency with complaints of vomiting and poor feeding. On examination, oil drop cataract is seen bilaterally. Biochemical evaluation shows the GALT enzymatic deficiency. On urine examination, what is the likely finding?
questions.solution:
• GALT enzyme is another name for Gal-1Phosphate Uridyl Transferase, which is deficient in Galactosemia
  • Galactose is elevated in blood and appears in urine
  • Benedict’s test is positive

questions.text: Chitotriosidase, TRAP and ACE enzymes are elevated. The following histopathological picture is seen on bone marrow examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gaucher’s Disease:

  • Most common lysosomal storage disorder.
  • β-glucosidase, aka, glucocerebrosidase and glucosylceramidase
  • Cherry red spot, mental retardation not seen.
  • Gaucher cells with wrinkled paper appearance.
  • Acute abdominal pain & bone crises.
  • Serum levels of chitotriosidase, ACE, TRAP, & chemokine CCL18/PARK are very high.

questions.text: Glutathione reductase activity deficient in blood, with history of tingling and numbness in both upper and lower limbs. Examination shows cheilosis, circumoral lesions and painful red tongue. Deficient vitamin is: (AI-2018-May-13)
questions.solution:
Riboflavin: Vitamin B2
• Dietary requirement is 0.5mg/1000kcal intake, not in terms of body mass.
• Biologically active form is FAD/FMN
• Deficiency is detected by measuring the activity of the enzyme glutathione reductase.
• Ariboflavinosis results in normochromic normocytic anemia and stomatitis, which presents as:
– painful red tongue with sore throat
– chapped and fissured lips (cheilosis) 
– inflammation of the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis)
• Deficiency is sometimes called pellagra sine pellagra', since the stomatitis of pellagra is similar.

questions.text: A 56-year-old homeless man presents to ER with increased fatigability and exertional dyspnea. Physical examination shows significant lower extremity edema and decreased sensation over the ankles and feet. Further evaluation reveals cardiac dilation and increased cardiac output. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Beri-Beri (Thiamine Deficiency)

  • Dry Beri Beri: -
    • It involves CNS in the form of paresthesia, general weakness, atrophy, foot and wrist drop.
  • Wet Beri Beri: -
    • It involves CVS in the form of palpitation, tachycardia, AR, edema, high cardiac output failure
  • Acute/Infant Beri Beri: -
    • Seen in those infants whose mothers milk is deficient in B1

questions.text: The lab reports of a patient given below: pH= 7.2, HCO3=10 mEq/L, PCO2=30 mmHg. This exemplifies which of the following disorder?

choices.text: Volume of Serum passing through kidney in 24 hour

questions.text: Which value is not required to measure Creatinine Clearance?
A person was diagnosed with Gout. You will suggest the patient to avoid which of the following food product in his diet?
questions.solution:
Common substances which predispose to gout:

  • Beer and alcohols
  • High fructose diet
  • Meats, especially with high content of liver; fish
  • Mushrooms
  • Drugs like thiazide diuretics
  • NSAIDs, chronic use

The 8993 T > G mutation in mitochondrial DNA has been associated with variable syndromes of differing severity ranging from maternally inherited

Clinical Diagnosis

Mitochondrial DNA associated (mtDNA-associated) Leigh syndrome and NARP are part of a continuum of progressive neurodegenerative disorders observed in members of the same family caused by abnormalities of mitochondrial energy generation.

NARP

Diagnosis of NARP is based on the following clinical features:

  • Neurogenic muscle weakness. Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies may demonstrate peripheral neuropathy (which may be a sensory or sensorimotor axonal polyneuropathy).
  • Ataxia. Cerebral and cerebellar atrophy may be noted on MRI.
  • Retinitis pigmentosa. The ocular manifestations of NARP are extremely variable and range from a mild salt and pepper retinopathy to bull's eye maculopathy and classic retinitis pigmentosa with bone spicule formation Ophthalmologic examination may reveal pigmentary retinopathy or optic atrophy. Electroretinogram (ERG) may reveal abnormalities (including small-amplitude waveform) or may be normal. ERG may demonstrate predominantly cone dysfunction in some pedigrees and mainly rod dysfunction in others.
  • In addition, neuropathy, seizures, and learning difficulties are usually present.

choices.text: An active process involving hydrolysis of ATP

questions.text:
A cell membrane is damaged by insertion of a microneedle; repair shall occur by
which of the following processes?
questions.solution:
• Membrane structure is described as “proteins floating in a sea of lipids”.


The fluid mosaic model of membrane structure

  • The membrane consists of a bimolecular lipid layer with proteins inserted in it or bound to either surface. Integral membrane proteins are firmly embedded in the lipid layers. Some of these proteins completely span the bilayer and are called transmembrane proteins, while others are embedded in either the outer or inner leaflet of the lipid bilayer. Loosely bound to the outer or inner surface of the membrane are the peripheral proteins.
  • The peripheral proteins are mobile, and can move laterally in this sea of lipids. Thus, they can help heal small damages in membrane structure by rearranging themselves via lateral movement.

questions.text: An afro-american kid of 6 years of age presented with abdominal pain, chronic hemolysis and abnormal RBC shape on peripheral smear. Most likely disorder responsible for this condition is:
questions.solution:
• Based on the patient profile, the condition is likely to be Sickle cell anemia, which is due to Point Mutation.
  • Base substitution/Point Mutation:


  • Silent Mutation: base substitution causes no change in coded amino acid.
  • Missense mutation: base substitution causes change in coded amino acid:
    • Acceptable m.s.m.
    • Partially acceptable m.s.m.
    • Unacceptable m.s.m.
  • Nonsense Mutation: base substitution introduces stop codon.
